ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

REPORT OF FOREIGN CORRESPONDENTS ON DETENTION OF LOCAL JOURNALISTS


    1. Dr Lau Teik Soon asked the Minister for Foreign Affair's if he will give his comments on the story reportedly carried in The Sunday Times of London that the detention of the local journalists and the statement about the involvement of the Editor of the Review have "seriously jeopardised its (Singapore's) international reputation", and whether in his view foreign correspondents resident in Singapore have

Column: 1522

any role to play in the foreign relations of the Republic.

    The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the hon. Member is referring to an article by a Mr William Shawcross in the Sunday Times of London of 13th March. In answering the hon. Member's question I am in danger of breaching a new convention which certain sections of the Western Press have developed in regard to criticism. If a pressman attacks a politician, that is free speech. But if the politician concerned hits back, then a hue and cry is raised that freedom of the press is in utter jeopardy. A point that has been lost sight of in recent press criticisms about the Singapore Government is that though we have, as a

Column: 1523

Government, often exercised our right to tell off certain foreign pressmen when we think them misguided, we have never arrested or deported any of them or banned their publications merely for critical and even ill-informed articles about Singapore.

    We have done so only when, from being mere observers and reporters, pressmen have become active partisans in our domestic affairs or, as a number of them did, got involved with subversion and the espousal of its cause.

    Sir, with regard to Mr William Shawcross' observation in the Sunday Times that the arrest of Singaporeans who have admitted to working with the communists has blackened Singapore's international reputation, it has about as much substance as that paper's efforts a few years ago to sell the Slater-Walker team to the world as model of 21st century entrepreneurs.

    Admittedly, Sir, the reputation of the Singapore Government has sunk rapidly in the eyes of a handful of British publications, like the Sunday Times, The Times, the Far Eastern Economic Review and the Economist. But these publications do not represent world opinion and our reputation with some 1 50 nations is as sound as ever before.

    Some hon. Members: Hear, hear!

    Mr Rajaratnam: No government or international financiers have told us officially or unofficially that they have lost confidence in the Singapore Government as a result of the recent arrests in Singapore. So I do not know what Mr Shawcross is talking about.

    As regards the Member's second half of the question, I am not quite sure what the hon. Member means when he asks whether "foreign correspondents resident in Singapore have any role to play in the foreign relations of the Republic." Perhaps what the Member has in mind is, to me, the astonishing conduct of some foreign newsmen in Singapore and the even more astonishing reaction of certain British publications to the arrest and confessions of Mr Arun and Mr Raman, among others. The

Column: 1524

coverage in a number of British papers of the public statements of Arun and Raman have not been so much factual reports as sceptical and selective evaluations of what was said by them. The general tenor of the reports was such as to leave in the minds of their readers the impressions that the confessions were rigged and that the people arrested were not really communists or communist supporters but victims of PAP intolerance.

    Yet, Mr Speaker, Sir, when the foreign press was invited to question Arun and Raman over TV, their silence was deafening. If Western pressmen really believed that the whole show was stage-managed, that the two gentlemen concerned had been either tortured or terrorised into admitting things they had not done, then one would have thought that here was an opportunity for the Western pressmen to expose by sharp and in-depth questioning of the two that the whole thing was rigged. Here was an opportunity.

    Sir, I can think of many occasions in Europe and America when newsmen were not averse to coming into TV studios, were not deterred by studio lights and batteries of TV cameras from grilling subjects who could provide them with news and, in this case, indeed most startling news had the newsmen been able to expose these confessions as a fraud.

    It was not that we had put any kind of restraints on the questions the newsmen could ask. There were none. In fact, the Chairman. Mr James Fu, had repeatedly asked the foreign pressmen to put questions and all this was greeted with what I can only describe as "studied silence". Clearly, the foreign newsmen had come determined and convinced that the cause of press freedom or some other cause could best be served by not being provoked into asking questions. This, in my view, is odd behaviour for men who earn their bread and butter and their reputation by asking awkward questions. I can only make a guess at this inexplicable lack of curiosity over confessions which had already been portrayed by sections of the Western press as manifestations of a police state.

Column: 1525



    My guess, Mr Speaker, is that the Western newsmen sensed from the evidence given to them that an intense grilling of Mr Arun and Mr Raman, far from weakening the Government's case, would only have strengthened it. It would have shattered the myth so elaborately built up in sections of the Western press that the PAP Government was dedicated to stamping out all dissent, crushing all political opponents and building up a totalitarian state. Had there been an intense cross-questioning by foreign pressmen of Arun and Raman, what would have in fact emerged was that we had detained a journalist who had knowingly played along with the communists, and a lawyer with affiliations with British Marxists, not averse, according to Mr Raman, to using violence to bring down the PAP Government. Had the Western newsmen actively participated in the interview, then they would have had to report it as such and report what actually happened and that would have left an impression in the minds of readers in the Western world that the detention was justified. So better keep quiet and leave undisturbed the impression that the TV press conference was rigged. Hence The Times of 18th March could with apparent honesty editorialise as follows:

    "The televised statements by Mr Raman and Mr Senkuttuvan, both of them hollow-sounding recitals with a dictated air - by whatever means they were extracted ...",

    That is, "the whole thing is phoney. Do not question. Just report what you think happened." Incidentally, Sir, the same paper dismissed the recent Singapore general elections in a couple of obscure paragraphs. It would not have suited The Times' carefully nurtured image of a tyrannical PAP Government to have given importance to the fact that it had instead won all seats for the third time and with an increased majority of the votes cast. So tuck it away.

    Similarly, thanks to the silence of the Western pressmen, the Economist of 19th March, the next day, permitted itself this little bit of detached comment, and I quote:

Column: 1526



    "Roll up for yet another public showing of the uglier face of Singapore's police state. On March 12. the Government persuaded two of the men arrested ... to confess to the error of their ways in a press conference on live television."

    Neither of the two journals concerned mentioned the pertinent fact that the Western pressmen were there at the conference and that they had not made the slightest attempt through interview to get at the facts, to get at the truth. Sir, the truth had already been arrived at before the press conference in the editorial offices in London and any fresh and conflicting evidence would be most unwelcome.

    Since the PAP Government and the voters of Singapore appear to be adamant in doing what they think is good for Singapore, the Sunday Times and Mr Shawcross have now carried British journalism into the murkier grounds of blackmail. Since they cannot persuade us by threats, what about blackmail. So he warned Singapore that (and I quote):

    "as Singapore depends on the international money market for its prosperity (the arrests) can prove counterproductive."

Telling us if we do not do what they say we must do, no more investments. That is how I read it.

    Mr Shawcross wants us to believe that were Singapore to release known and self-confessed Communists, stop broadcasting revelations by Communists and pro-Communists how they go about their furtive business of subversion, give immunity to those who, under cover of free speech, breach the laws of libel and slander and scrap the detention laws for which we have popular mandate then, according to Mr Shawcross, foreign investors would be streaming into Singapore, pockets full of money and with joy in their hearts.

    Perhaps Mr Shawcross has a pretty low opinion of Asian intelligence and especially of Singapore intelligence. On the contrary it is because we have not been following Mr Shawcross' advice that foreign investors have shown a growing interest in Singapore and increasing nervousness about those

Column: 1527

countries where the remedies Mr Shawcross suggests have been applied.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I have my own views as to why certain sections of the Western press, and in particular the British press, are going beyond the bounds of journalism to pressurise the Singapore Government into adopting policies which the people of Singapore know would bring back the lawlessness, violence, rioting, and economic stagnation which were features when the Communists and pro-Communists were allowed to run around. The Western press knows, including the Western pressmen here, that we are not crushing opposition. In the recent elections there were any number of parties. We are not crushing opposition which is lawful and constitutional but Communist opposition which is unlawful, and for the suppression of which we have full mandate from the people. And yet they go back, even now, and say we are crushing opposition, never saying we are crushing Communist opposition.

    So, Mr Speaker, Sir, under the pretence of upholding human rights and democracy in darkest Singapore, what this section of the press, of the British press in particular, is agitating for through distortion and even blackmail is rights for Communists and pro-Communists to run around once again in Singapore knowing full well what the consequences would be for Singapore.

    Is it that they want a revival of the old Singapore? Why is the press doing this? Well, Mr Speaker, that is another story for some other time. Are then the foreign correspondents resident in Singapore suspect? In my view, and I know many of them, most of them are just being straightforward newsmen. But some presumably are specially selected by their editors, including local journalists, for more than mere reporting. For example, Mr Derek Davies of the Far Eastern Economic Review has a flair (it must have been a well developed one, a very unusual flair) for choosing local malcontents for correspondents. I must assume that Mr Davies has carefully assessed their character

Column: 1528

before appointing them. He must therefore know that he will get biased, blunted and false reports from them. Mr Speaker, you may recollect a British press baron, Lord Northcliffe, if I am right, who said he never had to tell his editor what to write because the man he chose made this unnecessary. Or as a British poet put it more pungently (and I quote): 
                          

 `You cannot, thank God

 Bribe or twist

 A British journalist

 But seeing what the fellow will do

 Unbribed

 There's no occasion to.'


    Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to ask a supplementary question. When I asked the Hon. Minister whether foreign correspondents in Singapore have any role to play in the formation of our foreign policy, I implied that they really have no role at all, and I think the Minister's answer confirms that. However. I think we do welcome -

    Mr Speaker: Dr Lau, what is your supplementary question?

    Dr Lau Teik Soon: It is coming up, Sir. We welcome foreign correspondents but we expect them to play a proper role, as the Hon. Minister has mentioned; they should be straightforward newspaper men. In this connection, may I quote -

    Mr Speaker: Where is your supplementary question, Dr Lau?

    Dr Lau Teik Soon: I would like the Minister's comments on a further remark on the part of William Shawcross, and I quote:

    'There is speculation in Singapore that he (Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew) has decided to rid himself of an independent international press in the way he disposed of domestic press criticism.'

May I ask the Hon. Minister what the proper role of the foreign correspondents should be and would he advise the foreign correspondents here.

    Mr S. Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, we have not the slightest intention of getting rid of the foreign press. The foreign press may get rid of itself by itself. It is

Column: 1529

interesting, Sir, that Singapore is not the only country which seems to get into trouble with the Western press. All over Asia and Africa Western pressmen have been either arrested, deported or suspended. In fact, as I have said, in Singapore we have done none of these things. So there is a role for Western pressmen. I am not talking of all foreign correspondents because apart from the British press there has been no complaint from any foreign correspondent, neither from Izvestia nor from Peking nor from Hanoi. If he means by foreign correspondents the Western press, they have a role to play. "Please report as accurately as you can, even critically as you can, so long as you do not interfere in our internal affairs."

    Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. Why should the Government allow the specially selected foreign correspondents to be resident in Singapore if the scope of their activities is beyond the scope of journalism?

    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, we would not know when they are specially selected until after we have spotted them. And when we spot them we arrest them.

    Sir, it is noted that the sum appropriated for FY76 has not been utilised, hence the revote. Perhaps the Hon. Minister would care to enlighten this House as to the reasons why the Centralised Motor Repair Workshops have not been constructed, although provision for this has already been made.

    The House was informed yesterday by the Senior Minister of State that the Ministry is faced with the problem of resettling workshops, especially those that are in the city areas. I fail to understand how the Ministry concerned would be able to resettle such workshops unless the Centralised Motor Repair Workshops are ready for them to move in. Would not the Hon. Minister also enlighten this House as to where these workshops are to be located, when would construction commence and when would these workshops be completed.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon): Mr Speaker, Sir, the proposed site for the Centralised Motor Repair Workshop is at 19.3 km Woodlands Road. Plans and cost estimates for the project have been completed. The Ministry will proceed with the implementation of the project as soon as funds are available. Sir, the delay to implement this scheme was due to the fact that we had to get approval from the Development Planning Committee of the Finance Ministry.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, in view of the reply from the Parliamentary Secretary I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    That the sum to be allocated for Head O be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AAA 8104*. (* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr Ng Kah Ting).

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the main function of the Urban and Rural Services Committee is to look after the development of the rural areas in Singapore. Over the past decade the URSC has been quite successful in the development of the rural areas in Singapore. This

Column: 1531

achievement has helped to improve the standard of living of the rural people by the provision of electricity, better roads, water supply, etc. In other words, the URSC has brought to the rural people modern facilities in their environment.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, notwithstanding this achievement I notice from the provision that there is a sum of only $3.94 million for expenditure on so many rural areas. This is obviously insufficient and it is less than the provision for last year. We should increase this provision so that the various construction and development work in the rural areas can be proceeded with more expeditiously.

    Sir,I visit my constituents very often. In the course of my visits I notice that some recently constructed roads have a lot of potholes and driving becomes rather bumpy, so soon after the completion of the road.

3.00 p.m.

    What is the reason for this? Sir, I think this is because supervision of the work has not been carried out thoroughly. As a result of lack of proper supervision, unethical and irresponsible contractors have provided bad services at the expense of public money. In other words there have been malpractices. They have failed to construct the roads according to proper specifications. As a result, the roads deteriorate more rapidly than expected. This is a waste of public funds.

    On the other hand. Sir,I have also noticed that roads built under the gotong royong scheme are much better than those built by the contractors. Even after several years of use, these roads are still good. So I would like to propose that, where road construction is concerned, whether the job is big or small, we should encourage more people to participate in gotong royong rather than leaving this work of road construction entirely to contractors. By the spirit of gotong royong, we will be able to save costs and use the savings to construct still more. within the limited supply of funds.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, MPs representing the rural areas welcome the

Column: 1532

provision of $3.94 million for urban and rural services. However. Sir, it should be noted that item (h) of this subhead amounting to $339,990 is Expenditure Carried Forward. In other words, the total amount that will actually be utilised for urban and rural services for FY 77 is $3,600,010 to be exact.

    Whilst I must first give due credit to the Urban and Rural Services Committee under the chairmanship of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development in the last 14 years for the various amenities enumerated and have already been provided to the rural constituencies, I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to inform this House as to the total amount of monies spent up to date, in respect of the items listed. I shall also be grateful if he will be kind enough to state the total amounts spent on each item. Otherwise it may be construed, as implied by one hon. Member, ah, yes I think it is the hon. Member for Boon Lay who was reported to have said that the Chairman of URSC had nothing to inform the press of what URSC has done to the rural constituencies.

    Following this, Sir, I would like to draw the attention of the House in general and the Hon. Parliamentary Secretary in particular on the following observations:

    (1) Most of the kampong roads are now in dire need of repairs as they were metalled some years ago. These roads are full of potholes resulting in much inconvenience to the residents. Would not the URSC consider resurfacing them? These roads, moreover, are very narrow and need to be widened, I hope the URSC will consider this also.

    (2) The Street lighting in the kampongs is poor and brighter Street lamps should replace these lamps which in some cases are more than 10 years old.

    (3) Public standpipes were removed to enable households to connect piped-water into their homes. I would like to know how much has been spent on laying of water-mains to enable those affected to connect piped-water to their houses. How many households have benefitted as a result? and

Column: 1533



    (4) Last year. I submitted a question for Oral Answer concerning the making up of the various Farmways in the Pig Farming areas. The Hon. Minister for National Development and Communications replied that such requests would be favourably considered when submitted to the URSC.

    Sir, the Hon. Senior Minister of State in reply to questions on this matter yesterday, stated that it would take some time for the necessary infrastructure and services to be provided in this area.

    I believe that this will entail high costs and it is my contention that the URSC should not be made to bear such costs in fairness to the other rural constituencies for the simple reason that the sums allocated are definitely insufficient to meet the numerous requests of these constituencies.

    Therefore, Sir, I would like to reiterate that the URSC make out the necessary costing for such provision and that this matter be submitted to the Finance Ministry for approval.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, I would like to thank the Member for Sembawang and the Member for Punggol for their remarks on the Urban and Rural Services Committee and for making suggestions to the Committee. The Member for Sembawang has said that after repair of construction of roads in the rural areas, further repairs often become necessary and he has expressed the view that this was due to the lack of strict supervision. As a matter of fact, Sir, all road construction undertaken by contractors is supervised by officers of the Public Works Department very strictly. There is no need for us to worry about this aspect. Furthermore, Sir, it is also written in every tender contract that for the first six months contractors are held responsible for any defects or disrepair of the road after completion. The crux of the matter is that the newly completed metalled roads very often attract a lot more vehicles. As a result of excessive use of such roads, the neighbouring rural roads are also affected

Column: 1534

and become damaged. As soon as the URSC has got information of such a state of affairs, the PWD will be told to carry out immediate repairs to prevent further deterioration of the roads.

    The Member for Sembawang has also suggested that we should encourage more people to participate in road construction under the gotong royong scheme. As a matter of fact, Sir, this has always been encouraged by the URSC. In 1976 alone, in Chua Chu Kang. Punggol, Nee Soon, Jurong, Tampines and Kampong Chai Chee, we launched a gotong royong campaign for road construction in these areas. As a result, 18 rural roads were repaired or improved at a cost of $638,000. All these road construction works and improvement were completed according to schedule. Here, Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to express my thanks on behalf of the Government to all the rural people, the CCC, the MPs, national servicemen and the undergraduates of higher institutions of learning for their participation in these gotong royong projects. Sir, I can assure the Member for Sembawang that these collective gotong royong projects will continue to be encouraged by the Government and will receive all the necessary support of the Government.

    The Member for Sembawang has also asked for an increase in the provision of funds for the URSC. As a matter of fact, Sir, over the past few years, the Urban and Rural Services Committee has been given increasing funds from year to year. For example, in FY 1974-75, the provision for the URSC was $3.3 million whereas in FY 75-76 the provision was increased to $3.6 million. There was an increase of 9.8%. In FY 76-77, the provision was $3.98 million, an increase of 9.7%. For the new financial year of 77-78, the provision is $3.94 million. This may appear to be slightly less than the previous provision but, in actual fact, it is not so. I say so because in the previous provisions for the URSC there was included a sum of $1 million for the improvement of street lighting in the urban areas, and this amount has now been transferred to the PWD fund from the total allocation to the

Column: 1535

URSC. So if we were to include the $1 million for street lighting improvement in the city area, then the total allocation can be said to have increased by 25% over the previous year's provision.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I agree with the view expressed by the hon. Member for Punggol that the U RSC annual allocation of funds can only be used for the improvement of public amenities within the various constituencies. As regards the work for the new resettlement areas, such as the resettlement area in Jalan Kayu and Punggol, the pig farms, etc., the URSC will very soon make a careful study and survey of these two Constituencies to understand and to find out which public facilities need further improvement or greater attention. At the same time, the URSC will also make an estimate of the amount of money required for these facilities and action will be taken to ask the Ministry of Finance for the appropriation of funds. So the hon. Member can rest assured about this matter.

    As regards the matter raised by the Member for Punggol that the street lights in the rural areas provided by the URSC are not bright enough and should be improved, my answer is that his criticism is quite correct. As a matter of fact, Sir, the Urban and Rural Services Committee as far back as three years ago, looked into this matter very carefully. But, because in certain rural areas there were still no street lights available, so they could not as a matter of priority improve on the lighting conditions of the earlier existing lamps.

3.15 p.m.

    Now, because most of the roads in the rural areas are equipped with street lights, the URSC is now ready to do something to improve the poor lighting. In the past the street lights installed in some rural areas were 100 watt metal filament lamps. That was one type. The other type was the 40 watt flourescent tubes. The common feature of these two types of lighting is that they will only last two to three months. The maintenance cost therefore is very high. Three years ago the Urban and Rural Services Committee on an experimental

Column: 1536

basis used the 125 watt high pressure mercury vapour lamps and they found that this kind of light was much better. They find that the new type was eight times brighter than the old ones and they could last two to three years. This means a greater consumption of electricity. The URSC has decided to improve the existing lamps gradually over the next few years. In the more densely populated areas or in areas where there are community centres, priority will be given in the replacement of old lamps.

    If the rural roads built earlier are found to be in a very serious state of disrepair, the URSC is ever ready to consider taking immediate action to repair such roads as soon as possible. The Member for Punggol wanted to know the work of the URSC in the past 14 years from 1963 to 1976, in the improvement of public facilities in the rural and urban areas. Over the 14 years, the URSC has spent a total of $48,144 million for the improvement of the living environment of the rural people. This amount of money had been spent on the provisions for the following separate items: First, on rural roads, the expenditure amounted to $15.691 million. Second, the provision of street lighting which took up $8.96 million.

    Third, the provision of water pipes $6.288 million, under this scheme 11,542 households have been provided with water supply. That is to say, more than 103,800 people have benefitted. Fourth, rural electrification scheme which was completed by 1972 accounted for $13.624 million, benefitting about 1 62,000 people involving about 23,000 households. Fifth, improvement of jetties and other works $3.551 million. All these facts and figures show that of the $48.144 million mentioned earlier, about 74% of the money was spent on rural constituencies. This shows that the Government has done a great deal in improving the living conditions of the people in the rural areas. Nothwithstanding what we have done. there is still room in the rural areas which merit further consideration and attention from the URSC and further efforts will be made to improve such areas.

Column: 1537



    On the 16th of this month when the House was debating the estimates for the Ministry of Culture. the Member for Boon Lay raised the question as to why the URSC had not held press conferences as in the past. I would like to take this opportunity to give him a brief reply.
